<p class="cek"><span class="cbh">Glossary</span></p>
<p class="ceq"><span class="car">Technical and Industry Terms</span></p>
<div class="story-table-container"><table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="cji">
<tbody>
<tr class="jx">
<td class="jz">
<p class="cnh">4G data customer</p>
</td>
<td class="jz">
<p class="cni">A customer having a 4G handset and who has used at least 1MB on any of the Group's GPRS, 3G & 4G network in the last 30 days.</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="jx">
<td class="jw">
<p class="cnh">Airtel Money</p>
</td>
<td class="jw">
<p class="cni">Airtel Money is the brand name for Airtel Africa's mobile money products and services. The term is used interchangeably with "mobile money" when referring to our mobile money business, finance, operations and activities.</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="jx">
<td class="jw">
<p class="cnh">Airtel Money ARPU<br/>
(mobile money ARPU)</p>
</td>
<td class="jw">
<p class="cni">Mobile money average revenue per user. This is derived by dividing total mobile money revenue during the relevant period by the average number of active mobile money customers and dividing the result by the number of months in the relevant period.</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="jx">
<td class="jw">
<p class="cnh">Airtel Money customer base (mobile money customer base)</p>
</td>
<td class="jw">
<p class="cni">Total number of active subscribers who have enacted any mobile money usage event in last 30 days.</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="jx">
<td class="jw">
<p class="cnh">Airtel money customer penetration (mobile money customer penetration)</p>
</td>
<td class="jw">
<p class="cni">The proportion of total Airtel Africa active mobile customers who use mobile money services. Calculated by dividing the mobile money customer base by the Group's total customer base.</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="jx">
<td class="jw">
<p class="cnh">Airtel Money transaction value (mobile money transaction value)</p>
</td>
<td class="jw">
<p class="cni">Any financial transaction performed on Airtel Africa's mobile money platform.</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="jx">
<td class="jw">
<p class="cnh">Airtel money transaction value per customer per month (mobile money transaction value per customer per month)</p>
</td>
<td class="jw">
<p class="cni">Calculated by dividing the total mobile money transaction value on the Group's mobile money platform during the relevant period by the average number of active mobile money customers and dividing the result by the number of months in the relevant period.</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="jx">
<td class="jw">
<p class="cnh">ARPU</p>
</td>
<td class="jw">
<p class="cni">Average revenue per user per month. This is derived by dividing total revenue during the relevant period by the average number of customers during the period and dividing the result by the number of months in the relevant period.</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="jx">
<td class="jw">
<p class="cnh">Average customers</p>
</td>
<td class="jw">
<p class="cni">The average number of active customers for a period. Derived from the monthly averages during the relevant period. Monthly averages are calculated using the number of active customers at the beginning and the end of each month.</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="jx">
<td class="jw">
<p class="cnh">Broadband base stations</p>
</td>
<td class="jw">
<p class="cni">Base stations that carry either 3G and/or 4G capability across all technologies and spectrum bands.</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="jx">
<td class="jw">
<p class="cnh">Capital expenditure</p>
</td>
<td class="jw">
<p class="cni">An alternative performance measure (non-GAAP). Defined as investment in gross fixed assets (both tangible and intangible but excluding spectrum and licences) plus capital work in progress (CWIP), excluding provisions on CWIP for the period.</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="jx">
<td class="jw">
<p class="cnh">Constant currency</p>
</td>
<td class="jw">
<p class="cni">The Group has presented certain financial information that is calculated by translating the results for the current financial year and previous financial years at a fixed 'constant currency' exchange rate, which is done to measure the organic performance of the Group. Growth rates for business and product segments are in constant currency as it better represent the underlying performance of the business. Constant currency growth for prior years are calculated using closing exchange rates as at the end of prior year.</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="jx">
<td class="jw">
<p class="cnh">Churn</p>
</td>
<td class="jw">
<p class="cni">Churn is derived by dividing the total number of customer disconnections during the relevant period by the average number of customers and dividing the result by number of months in the relevant period.</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="jx">
<td class="jw">
<p class="cnh">Customer</p>
</td>
<td class="jw">
<p class="cni">Defined as a unique active subscriber with a unique mobile telephone number who has used any of Airtel's services in the last 30 days.</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="jx">
<td class="jw">
<p class="cnh">Customer base</p>
</td>
<td class="jw">
<p class="cni">The total number of active subscribers that have used any of our services (voice calls, SMS, data usage or mobile money transaction) in the last 30 days.</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="jx">
<td class="jw">
<p class="cnh">Data ARPU</p>
</td>
<td class="jw">
<p class="cni">Data ARPU is derived by dividing total data revenue during the relevant period by the average number of data customers and dividing the result by the number of months in the relevant period.</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="jx">
<td class="jw">
<p class="cnh">Data customer base</p>
</td>
<td class="jw">
<p class="cni">The total number of subscribers who have consumed at least 1MB on the Group's GPRS, 3G or 4G network in the last 30 days.</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="jx">
<td class="jw">
<p class="cnh">Data customer penetration</p>
</td>
<td class="jw">
<p class="cni">The proportion of customers using data services. Calculated by dividing the data customer base by the total customer base.</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="jx">
<td class="jw">
<p class="cnh">Data usage per customer</p>
</td>
<td class="jw">
<p class="cni">Calculated by dividing the total MBs consumed on the Group's network during the relevant period by the average data customer base over the same period and dividing the result by the number of months in the relevant period.</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="jx">
<td class="jw">
<p class="cnh">Diluted earnings per share</p>
</td>
<td class="jw">
<p class="cni">Diluted EPS is calculated by adjusting the profit for the year attributable to the shareholders and the weighted average number of shares considered for deriving basic EPS, for the effects of all the shares that could have been issued upon conversion of all dilutive potential shares. The dilutive potential shares are adjusted for the proceeds receivable had the shares actually been issued at fair value. Further, the dilutive potential shares are deemed converted as at beginning of the period, unless issued at a later date during the period.</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="jx">
<td class="jw">
<p class="cnh">Earnings per share (EPS)</p>
</td>
<td class="jw">
<p class="cni">EPS is calculated by dividing the profit for the period attributable to the owners of the company by the weighted average number of ordinary shares outstanding during the period.</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="jx">
<td class="jw">
<p class="cnj">Foreign exchange rate movements for non-DTA operating companies</p>
<p class="cnh">and holding companies</p>
</td>
<td class="jw">
<p class="cni">Foreign exchange rate movements are specific items that are non-tax deductible in a few of our operating entities, hence these hinder a like-for-like comparison of the Group's effective tax rate on a period-to-period basis and are therefore excluded when calculating the effective tax rate.</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="jx">
<td class="jw">
<p class="cnh">Free cash flow</p>
</td>
<td class="jw">
<p class="cni">An alternative performance measure (non-GAAP). Free cash flow is defined as operating free cash flow less cash interest, income tax paid and change in operating working capital.</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="jx">
<td class="jv">
<p class="cnh">Information and communication technologies (ICT)</p>
</td>
<td class="jv">
<p class="cni">ICT refers to all communication technologies, including the internet, wireless networks, cell phones, computers, software, middleware, videoconferencing, social networking, and other media applications and services.</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="jx">
<td class="jw">
<p class="cnh">Interconnect user charges (IUC)</p>
</td>
<td class="jw">
<p class="cni">Interconnect user charges are the charges paid to the telecom operator on whose network a call is terminated.</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="jx">
<td class="jw">
<p class="cnh">Lease liability</p>
</td>
<td class="jw">
<p class="cni">Lease liability represents the present value of future lease payment obligations.</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="jx">
<td class="jw">
<p class="cnh">Leverage</p>
</td>
<td class="jw">
<p class="cni">An alternative performance measure (non-GAAP). Leverage (or leverage ratio) is calculated by dividing net debt at the end of the relevant period by the underlying EBITDA for the preceding 12 months.</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="jx">
<td class="jw">
<p class="cnh">Minutes of usage</p>
</td>
<td class="jw">
<p class="cni">Minutes of usage refer to the duration in minutes for which customers use the Group's network for making and receiving voice calls. It is typically expressed over a period of one month. It includes all incoming and outgoing call minutes, including roaming calls.</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="jx">
<td class="jw">
<p class="cnh">Mobile services</p>
</td>
<td class="jw">
<p class="cni">Mobile services are our core telecom services, mainly voice and data services, but also including revenue from tower operation services provided by the Group and excluding mobile money services.</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="jx">
<td class="jw">
<p class="cnh">Net debt</p>
</td>
<td class="jw">
<p class="cni">An alternative performance measure (non-GAAP). The Group defines net debt as borrowings including lease liabilities less cash and cash equivalents, term deposits with banks, processing costs related to borrowings and fair value hedge adjustments.</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="jx">
<td class="jw">
<p class="cnj">Net debt to underlying EBITDA (LTM)</p>
</td>
<td class="jw">
<p class="cni">An alternative performance measure (non-GAAP) Calculated by dividing net debt as at the end of the relevant period by underlying EBITDA for the preceding 12 months (from the end of the relevant period). This is also referred to as the leverage ratio.</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="jx">
<td class="jw">
<p class="cnh">Network towers or "sites"</p>
</td>
<td class="jw">
<p class="cni">Physical network infrastructure comprising a base transmission system (BTS) which holds the radio transceivers (TRXs) that define a cell and coordinates the radio link protocols with the mobile device. It includes all ground-based, roof top and in-building solutions.</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="jx">
<td class="jw">
<p class="cnh">Operating company (OpCo)</p>
</td>
<td class="jw">
<p class="cni">Operating company (or OpCo) is a defined corporate business unit, providing telecoms services and mobile money services in the Group's footprint.</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="jx">
<td class="jw">
<p class="cnh">Operating free cash flow</p>
</td>
<td class="jw">
<p class="cni">An alternative performance measure (non-GAAP). Calculated by subtracting capital expenditure from underlying EBITDA.</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="jx">
<td class="jw">
<p class="cnh">Operating leverage</p>
</td>
<td class="jw">
<p class="cni">An alternative performance measure (non-GAAP). Operating leverage is a measure of the operating efficiency of the business. It is calculated by dividing operating expenditure (excluding regulatory charges) by total revenue.</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="jx">
<td class="jw">
<p class="cnh">Operating profit</p>
</td>
<td class="jw">
<p class="cni">Operating profit is a GAAP measure of profitability. Calculated as revenue less operating expenditure (including depreciation and amortisation, and operating exceptional items).</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="jx">
<td class="jw">
<p class="cnh">Other revenue</p>
</td>
<td class="jw">
<p class="cni">Other revenue includes revenues from messaging, value added services (VAS), enterprise, site sharing and handset sale revenue.</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="jx">
<td class="jw">
<p class="cnh">Reported currency</p>
</td>
<td class="jw">
<p class="cni">Our reported currency is US dollars. Accordingly, actual periodic exchange rates are used to translate the local currency financial statements of OpCos into US dollars. Under reported currency the assets and liabilities are translated into US dollars at the exchange rates prevailing at the reporting date whereas the statements of profit and loss are translated into US dollars at monthly average exchange rates.</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="jx">
<td class="jw">
<p class="cnh">Smartphone</p>
</td>
<td class="jw">
<p class="cni">A smartphone is defined as a mobile phone with an interactive touch screen that allows the user to access the internet and additional data applications, providing additional functionality to that of a basic phone which is used only for making voice calls and sending and receiving text messages.</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="jx">
<td class="jw">
<p class="cnh">Smartphone penetration</p>
</td>
<td class="jw">
<p class="cni">Calculated by dividing the number of smartphone devices in use by the total number of customers.</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="jx">
<td class="jw">
<p class="cnh">Total MBs on network</p>
</td>
<td class="jw">
<p class="cni">Total MBs consumed (uploaded & downloaded) by customers on the Group's GPRS, 3G and 4G network during the relevant period.</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="jx">
<td class="jw">
<p class="cnh">Underlying EBIT</p>
</td>
<td class="jw">
<p class="cni">An alternative performance measure (non-GAAP). Defined as operating profit before exceptional items.</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="jx">
<td class="jw">
<p class="cnh">Underlying EBITDA</p>
</td>
<td class="jw">
<p class="cni">An alternative performance measure (non-GAAP). Defined as operating profit before depreciation, amortisation, CSR cost and exceptional items.</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="jx">
<td class="jw">
<p class="cnh">Underlying EBITDA margin</p>
</td>
<td class="jw">
<p class="cni">An alternative performance measure (non-GAAP). Calculated by dividing underlying EBITDA for the relevant period by underlying revenue for the relevant period.</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="jx">
<td class="jw">
<p class="cnh"><span class="ju">Unstructured Supplementary Service Data</span></p>
</td>
<td class="jw">
<p class="cni"><span class="ju">Unstructured Supplementary Service Data (USSD), also known as "quick codes" or "feature codes", is a communications protocol for GSM mobile operators, similar to SMS messaging. It has a variety of uses such as WAP browsing, prepaid callback services, mobile-money services, location-based content services, menu-based information services, and for configuring phones on the network.</span></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="jx">
<td class="jw">
<p class="cnh">Voice minutes of usage per customer per month</p>
</td>
<td class="jw">
<p class="cni">Calculated by dividing the total number of voice minutes of usage on the Group's network during the relevant period by the average number of customers and dividing the result by the number of months in the relevant period.</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="jx">
<td class="jt">
<p class="cnh">Weighted average number of shares</p>
</td>
<td class="jt">
<p class="cni">The weighted average number of shares is calculated by multiplying the number of outstanding shares by the portion of the reporting period those shares covered, doing this for each portion and then summing the total.</p>
</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table></div>

<tr class="bap">

<p class="cnm">KYC</p>
</td>
<td class="jl" style="width:479">
<p class="cnn">Know your customer</p>
</td>

<tr class="bap">
<td class="jm" style="width:145">
<p class="cnm">LTE</p>
</td>
<td class="jl" style="width:479">
<p class="cnn">Long-term evolution (4G technology)</p>
</td>

<tr class="bap">
<td class="jm" style="width:145">

<p class="cnk"><span class="caw">Risk Factors </span></p>
<p class="cnp"><span class="ayv">The Group's business and the industry in which it operates, together with all other information contained in this document, including, in particular, the risk factors summarized below. Additional risks and uncertainties relating to the Group that are not currently known to the Group, or that the Group currently deem immaterial, may individually or cumulatively also have a material adverse effect on the Group's business, results of operations and financial condition.</span></p>
<p class="cnp"><span class="ayv"> </span></p>
<p class="cnq"><span class="ais">Principal risks summarised </span></p>
<p class="cnr"><span class="ais">1.     We operate in an increasingly competitive environment and aggressive competition by existing players, or the entry of a new player could put a downward pressure on prices, adversely affecting our revenue and profitability. </span></p>
<p class="cnr"><span class="ais">2.     Failure to innovate through simplifying the customer experience, developing adequate digital touchpoints in line with changing customer needs and competitive landscape could lead to loss of customers and market share.</span></p>
<p class="cnr"><span class="ais">3.     An inability to invest and upgrade our network and IT infrastructure would affect our ability to compete effectively in the market.</span></p>
<p class="cnr"><span class="ais">4.     Cybersecurity threats through internal or external sabotage or system vulnerabilities could potentially result in customer data breaches and/or service downtimes. </span></p>
<p class="cnr"><span class="ais">5.     Adverse changes in our external business environment and / or supply chain processes leading to a significant increase in our operating cost structure and negatively impacting profitability. </span></p>
<p class="cnr"><span class="ais">6.     Due to shortage of skilled telecommunications professionals in some markets, inability identify and develop successors for key leadership positions could lead to disruptions in the execution of our corporate strategy. </span></p>
<p class="cnr"><span class="ais">7.     Our internal control environment is subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate due to changes in internal or external conditions, new accounting requirements, delays, or inaccuracies in reporting. </span></p>
<p class="cnr"><span class="ais">8.     Our telecommunications networks are subject to risks of technical failures, aging infrastructure, human error, wilful acts of destruction or natural disasters. </span></p>
<p class="cnr"><span class="ais">9.     Our multinational footprint means we are exposed to the risk of currency fluctuations including the availability of funds for repatriation to the Group company triggered by adverse macroeconomic conditions in the markets where we operate. </span></p>
<p class="cns"><span class="ais">10.  We operate in a diverse and dynamic legal and regulatory environment. A failure to comply with relevant laws and regulations could lead to regulatory penalties, sanctions, and reputational damage.</span></p>
<p class="cnr"><span class="ais">11.  Disruptions and uncertainties caused by the Covid-19 pandemic may impact the Group's ability to operate its business effectively and achieve its objectives.</span></p>
